transcript.text: There's something that's been bothering me. It started with a very simple observation. Anytime a new tech event or a hype cycle happens, right? It has the same energy. Honestly, I was getting tired of it. We've heard this story. VR was going to change everything. Crypto was going to replace money. We still have money. You and I were going to meet in the metaverse. Hasn't happened. Nothing has happened. It's all a hype. But then I read this report primarily because it was Mary Miker, queen of the internet, former Wall Street analyst forecasted the rise of companies like Google, Amazon, and Spotify. Mary Mer has always been right about anything that she's predicted. And so if she launched a report, I had to read. And after reading all 336 pages, which took 2 weeks by the way, I realized something that honestly kept me up at night. This AI phenomenon does not feel like VR or crypto or the metaverse. This is different. This is happening faster, spreading wider and reshaping the entire world as we know it. I have also been missing the scale at which AI is growing. This video is our attempt to show you what we've discovered after reading the report. Because if Mary Maker is right, and she usually is, we're not just watching another tech trend. We're watching the fastest transformation of the human civilization and it's happening right now. We are now glad to be a part of the 01 media network by Zerodha. Let's get back into the episode. How long do you think it takes for a new technology to reach 100 million users? The telephone took 50 years to reach 50% of American households. Television took 30 years. Netflix took 10 years to reach 100 million users. Facebook did that in just 4 years. Instagram did that in just 2 years. Did you notice something? Every time a new technology is coming, it's growing at two times the speed of the previous one. So, Chad GPT should have taken 1 year to reach the same number. But that's where AI is changing the rules completely. Chad GPT did 100 million users in just 60 days. And I got thinking, why is it growing so fast? Here's what we think is happening. If you want customers to come and use your product, you typically need a bunch of things to make that happen. If you sold cars, you need good roads. You need access to pedal bombs. And you need a distributor who will help you sell the product. Even Instagram or YouTube, you need cheap data to consume content. Thanks to Jio, the adoption of these tools have exploded. But with chat GPT, everything what it needs is already there. The timing couldn't have been more perfect. AI needed three things in abundance. Data, compute, and easy access to users. AI got all the data from internet. 30 years of people like you and I sharing knowledge online was fed into it, which is why it became so useful. Second was compute. AI needed a lot of powerful GPUs and hardware to be trained on. hardware has gotten so powerful that even the smartphone that you use is 10,000 times more powerful than the computer that was used by the astronauts that landed on the moon. And finally, easy access to users. Almost every single person has a smartphone with data access. This means that chat GPT was available to everyone instantly all at once. Did you know that 63% of developers are building with AI? That means the market is going to explode with AI first products that are going to disrupt every single industry. Yes, every single one. No one is prepared for the kind of disruption that is about to hit the market. Before we go ahead, I need a minute of yours. I'm sure if you've watched our videos before, you've heard us talk about the Kodas community. We are a community of 4,000 plus leaders and operators from Apple, Tik Tok, Slack, Zoom, Spotify, Canva, Lemon Labs, Nike, and more. What do they get? They get three unfair advantages. First, access to in-person meetups hosted every single week across 11 Indian cities, plus an online community where the world's top operators are just one message away. Second, they get to learn from the world's best folks across every single topic you can think of. AI, strategy, product growth, brand, you name it. And last, but definitely not the least, they get access to a $100,000 worth of exclusive perks from the top brands in the world like Wework, Notion, Mochabara, Lens Card, and a lot more. You can explore about Rubex in the link in the description. Here's a question that will connect everything we just spoke about. What happens when millions of people who use chatg, the millions of developers that are using it, plus thousands of companies all want to use AI at the same time? You get the largest infrastructure building plan in human history. Last year, the biggest tech companies spent $212 billion on infrastructure. That's not revenue. That's not market cap. That's actual money spent on servers, data centers, and chips. That's more than the GDP of most countries. Let me show you what 212 billion actually looks like. This is XAI's colossal facility in Memphis, Tennessee. 7 lakh 50,000 square ft having 2 lakh high-end GPUs built in just 3 months. Even a residential house takes 6 to 12 months to be built. And that's not it. Donald Trump has announced projects target to build AI infrastructure in the US. This project alone costs more than $500 billion. That's a lot of data centers and data centers need electricity. These facilities use enormous amount of electricities. Data centers already consume 1.5% of all global electricity and demand is growing exponentially. Even though our chips are getting 1 lakh times, yes one lakh times more efficient, total energy consumption is still rising because demand is growing much much faster than efficiency. I think we are going to see electricity coming from nuclear power becoming the norm. Now if any country wants to win the AI war, it's going to come down to infrastructure. There are two kinds of AI systems right now, open and closed. A closed system is like let's say the iPhone's iOS. Apple controls everything about it and you can't change how it works or see the code behind it. An open system is like Android. Anyone can look at the code, make changes or even create their own version of it like Samsung, Xiaomi, OnePlus, etc. For the last 2 years, if you wanted the best AI, you had two options. You either pay open AAI for chat jeopthic for claude. Both of these were closed systems, expensive to run, controlled by American companies. It felt like US had an enormous lead. And then this happened. Deep Seek. Deep Seek. Deep Seek. Deep Seek. Meet Deep Seek. Chinese built 100% open-source. It's also mighty powerful. On advanced reasoning tests, Deepseek scores 93%. OpenAI's latest model scores 95%. So, the difference is just 2%. But the most impressive part, Deepseek is 10 times cheaper than OpenAs's models. This changes everything because if you can get nearly the same performance but the model is 10 times cheaper, why would you pay the expensive version? One reason could be that data privacy issues with Chinese companies. But Deepsec is open source, so you can host it on your own servers and infrastructure and it's working. China's share of LLM usage jumped from 10% to 21% in just 12 months. And it's not just China. The entire open-source ecosystem is exploding. Meta has its own open-source model, Llama. This opensource model has been downloaded 1.2 billion times. To top it all, Meta just spent $15 billion to acquire Scale AI, a company that works on data labeling. And Zuck isn't stopping there. There have been reports that Meta is trying to poach top AI talent by offering them jaw-dropping salaries of $100 million. That's 900 cr rupees for a yearly salary. Oh man. The fundamental reason why everyone is going so hard on AI is because this isn't about technology. It's about power. AI leadership will determine geopolitical leadership, not the other way around. Here's something that confused me for a long time. If AI is as transformative as everyone says, why doesn't it feel like it's everywhere? I mean, you might use chat GBT. Maybe your company has talked about AI initiatives, but it still feels like, you know, optional, right? Well, it turns out that while we've been debating whether AI is overhyped, some of the world's biggest companies have been quietly integrating it into everything. Let me show you what I mean. This is Bank of America's AI assistant called Erica. Sounds harmless, just another chatbot. Erica has handled 2 billion customer interactions. That's not a beta program. That's not an experiment. That's a fullscale product handling billions of customer interactions. JP Morgan has 200 plus AI use cases in production. 50% of the S&P 500 companies mentioned AI in their recent earnings call. Do you see what's happening here? While we've been treating AI like it's experimental, it's becoming the norm. While we've been debating its potential is becoming productive. Everything we've talked about so far, the user adoption, the infrastructure, the competition, the enterprise deployment, that's all happening in the digital world. But AI is not stopping there. It's coming to the physical world and it's coming fast. One question that I started having when I was reading the report is that what happens when AI stops being software and starts being physically everywhere. Let me show you what I mean. In 2023 alone, the FDA approved 223 AI enabled medical devices. They're not apps. These are machines that diagnose cancer, assist in surgery, and manage drug discovery. The FDA just announced that they're integrating AI across all their centers by June 2025. We're talking about the agency that regulates food and medical being powered by artificial intelligence. In San Francisco, Whimo, the autonomous cab hailing service, went from 0% to 27% market share of ride share bookings in just 20 months. Tesla's full self-driving has logged 100 times more autonomous miles than it did last 3 years ago. And is building AI powered defense systems with revenue doubling year-over-year. We're talking about autonomous weapon systems and counter drone technology. Carbon Robotics has AI laser systems, eliminating weeds across two lakh 30,000 acres without herbicides. Countries around the world are treating AI infrastructure like they once treated highways and power grids as critical as national infrastructure. Because whoever controls AI doesn't just control software. They're controlling manufacturing, logistics, defense, medicine, energy, agriculture. Everything that happens in the physical world will be affected by AI. Do you remember that competition we talked about earlier? China has more industrial robots than the rest of the world combined. They are not just building better AI models. They are building AI powered infrastructure. It's predicted in the next 5 years we will have robot factories that are building more robots. That means robots are building more robots and that means an explosion of humanoid AI powered devices in the physical world. The transformation from digital AI to physical AI is happening faster than anyone predicted. So let me come back to that question I started with. Why is this AI different from VR or crypto or the metaverse? because those were additions to our existing world. AI is a replacement. Everything we talked about, the 800 million users of chat GPT, the 200 plus billion dollars in infrastructure, the geopolitical competition, the enterprise adoption, the physical world integration. analysis.main_summary:
This video analyzes the rapid and transformative impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) compared to previous technology hype cycles like VR, crypto, and the metaverse. The main thesis is that AI is fundamentally different due to its speed of adoption, widespread application, and potential to reshape the entire world, both digital and physical.

**Supporting Arguments:**

1.  **Unprecedented Adoption Rate:** The video highlights how quickly AI, specifically ChatGPT, reached 100 million users (60 days) compared to other technologies like telephones (50 years), television (30 years), Netflix (10 years), Facebook (4 years), and Instagram (2 years). It attributes this rapid growth to the perfect timing of AI's arrival, coinciding with the abundance of three key elements: data (from the internet), compute (powerful GPUs), and easy access to users (smartphones with data).
2.  **Infrastructure Building:** The video emphasizes the massive investment in AI infrastructure, with tech companies spending $212 billion on servers, data centers, and chips, exceeding the GDP of many countries. Examples include XAI's colossal facility in Memphis and Donald Trump's $500 billion AI infrastructure project. This rapid infrastructure development underscores the seriousness with which global players are pursuing AI dominance.
3.  **Geopolitical Competition:** The video highlights the open-source AI models, particularly Deepseek from China, as a potential game-changer. Deepseek, a 100% open-source model, performs nearly as well as OpenAI's models but is significantly cheaper (10 times). This is fueling the growth of the open-source ecosystem and shifting the balance of power. Meta's investment in Scale AI and attempts to poach top AI talent with exorbitant salaries are also mentioned. AI leadership is seen as a key determinant of geopolitical power.
4.  **Enterprise Integration:** The video debunks the perception of AI as merely experimental, showcasing its integration into major corporations. Bank of America's AI assistant, Erica, handles billions of customer interactions. JP Morgan has 200+ AI use cases in production. Over 50% of S\&P 500 companies mentioned AI in their recent earnings calls. AI is becoming productive and integrated into everyday business operations.
5.  **Shift to Physical World:** The video argues that AI is not confined to the digital realm but is rapidly expanding into the physical world. Examples include the FDA's approval of 223 AI-enabled medical devices, Waymo's increasing market share in ride-sharing, Tesla's advancements in full self-driving, and Carbon Robotics' AI laser systems for weed elimination. AI is impacting manufacturing, logistics, defense, medicine, energy, and agriculture. China's dominance in industrial robots is also highlighted, suggesting a future of AI-powered robot factories.

**Conclusion:**

The video concludes that AI is a replacement, not just an addition, to the existing world. The simultaneous occurrence of rapid user adoption, massive infrastructure investment, intense geopolitical competition, widespread enterprise adoption, and the integration of AI into the physical world sets it apart from previous technology trends. The window for adapting to AI is shrinking, measured in months or even days. The video urges viewers to study the Bond Capital report and prepare for the rapid changes ahead, emphasizing that the next 12 months in AI will be transformative.
key_takeaways: **AI Adoption is Happening Exponentially Faster Than Previous Technologies:** Forget incremental growth. AI adoption is breaking historical trends, with tools like ChatGPT reaching massive user bases in record time. This demands immediate attention and adaptation.
**AI Needs Infrastructure:** The widespread use of AI requires significant investment in the infrastructure, data centers, and powerful GPU systems.

**Open-Source AI is a Game Changer:** Open-source AI models, like DeepSeek and Llama, are democratizing access and driving innovation, potentially challenging the dominance of closed systems. Data privacy remains a concern.
**AI is About Power, Not Just Technology:** AI leadership translates to geopolitical influence. Countries are investing heavily in AI infrastructure, recognizing its strategic importance.

**AI is Quietly Integrating into Everything:** AI is not just a future concept; it's being silently integrated into essential services and industries like banking (Bank of America's Erica) and healthcare (FDA-approved AI devices). Companies mentioning AI in their earning calls means it is becoming normalized.

**AI is Transitioning to the Physical World:** AI is moving beyond software and impacting the physical world through robotics, autonomous vehicles (Waymo, Tesla), AI powered defense systems, and even agriculture (Carbon Robotics). This is where the transformative power will be most felt.

**The Time to Adapt is Now:** The window for understanding and adapting to AI is rapidly shrinking. Procrastination can lead to significant competitive disadvantages for individuals, companies, and even countries.

**Learn from Mary Meeker's Insights:** Pay attention to industry forecasts and analyses, particularly those from respected figures like Mary Meeker, to anticipate major technological shifts. The full bond capital report will be linked below. Read it, study it because the next 12 months in AI are going to feel like the next decade.
important_quotes: This AI phenomenon does not feel like VR or crypto or the metaverse. This is different. This is happening faster, spreading wider and reshaping the entire world as we know it.
AI leadership will determine geopolitical leadership, not the other way around.
While we've been treating AI like it's experimental, it's becoming the norm. While we've been debating its potential is becoming productive.

Whoever controls AI doesn't just control software. They're controlling manufacturing, logistics, defense, medicine, energy, agriculture. Everything that happens in the physical world will be affected by AI.
action_items: **Read** the full Bond Capital report by Mary Meeker. The transcript emphasizes its importance and provides the link.
**Explore** and experiment with Deepseek, the open-source AI model, considering its cost-effectiveness compared to closed systems like OpenAI.
**Identify** potential AI integrations within your industry or workplace. Consider how AI can replace or optimize existing processes.
**Research** the growing need for electricity generation, especially nuclear power, driven by AI infrastructure and data centers.
**Assess** and develop a data privacy strategy. Consider hosting open-source AI models on your own servers to address concerns about data privacy issues with foreign companies.

**Join** or engage with the Kodas community mentioned in the transcript to gain access to resources, networking, and learning opportunities related to AI and other areas. Use the link in the description of the video.
**Evaluate** your company or personal readiness for AI adoption. Identify skills gaps, infrastructure needs, and strategic opportunities.
**Investigate** AI-enabled medical devices and their impact on healthcare, especially considering the FDA's integration of AI across its centers by June 2025.

questions_and_answers.question: Why is the AI phenomenon different from previous tech hype cycles like VR, crypto, and the metaverse?
questions_and_answers.answer: Unlike those technologies, AI is happening faster, spreading wider, and reshaping the entire world as we know it. It's also being integrated into existing systems and processes at a rapid pace, rather than being an optional addition.

questions_and_answers.question: What three key factors have enabled the rapid growth and adoption of AI?
questions_and_answers.answer: Abundant data (from the internet), powerful computing infrastructure (GPUs and hardware), and easy access to users (via smartphones and internet connectivity).

questions_and_answers.question: Why are companies investing so heavily in AI infrastructure?
questions_and_answers.answer: Because AI leadership will determine geopolitical leadership. Countries want to control AI-powered manufacturing, logistics, defense, medicine, energy, and agriculture.

questions_and_answers.question: Why are closed AI systems like ChatGPT not the only option?
questions_and_answers.answer: Open-source models like DeepSeek are emerging, offering comparable performance at a significantly lower cost, allowing for greater flexibility and control.

questions_and_answers.question: How is AI moving beyond the digital world and impacting the physical world?
questions_and_answers.answer: AI is being integrated into medical devices, autonomous vehicles, robotics, and defense systems, transforming industries and infrastructure.
